Subject
2. Presentation of the 2021-22 Board President's Scholarship Awards
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: Board President Sharon Whitehurst-Payne and representatives from California Coast Credit Union will present Board President's Scholarships to the following district classified employees who are studying to become teachers:

 

  • Katerin Figueroa Rodriguez -  Special Education Technician, Chollas Mead Elementary School
  • Vania Griswold -  Special Education Assistant, Chollas Mead Elementary School
  • Edward LaSalle - Special Education Behavior Assistant, Central Elementary School
  • Keara Nelson -  Paraeducator Independence Facilitator, Pershing Middle School
  • Maria Nelson -  Paraeducator Independence Facilitator, Encanto Elementary School
  • Rebecca Taylor -  Paraeducator Independence Facilitator, Lewis Middle School

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Board President’s Scholarship program was established in 1994 by former Board Member John de Beck, in partnership with California Coast Credit Union. The scholarship awards are presented annually by the President of the Board of Education and local financial institution partners.  The 2021-22 scholarships are funded by California Coast Credit Union, and are awarded to six monthly classified employees who are working toward becoming teachers. California Coast Credit union contributed an endowment of $6,000.00 to fund the scholarships. The scholarship recipients will each receive a $1,000.00 check; which is to be used for tuition, fees, or books at any local two- or four-year accredited college or university.

 

[Originator/Contact: Marty Stultz, Director, Board Services, 619.725.5550, mstultz@sandi.net]

Subject
3. Recognition of Employees for Years of Service (40, 30, 20, 15, 10 and 5 Years of Service) & AASD Distinguished Leader Recognition
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: As a service-providing organization, the San Diego Unified School District's employees are its most valuable resource. Today's recognition includes recognition of employees with 40, 30, 20, 15, 10 and 5 years of service. Additionally, the District annually recognizes the AASD Distinguished Leaders. The Superintendent and the Board of Education extend their most sincere gratitude to these individuals. 

 

Today, we celebrate the total milestones of 68 for the month of May and June 2022, employees and the accomplishments of 14 certificated and classified leaders.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Monthly recognition, meant to celebrate and acknowledge employees who have hit notable career milestones with the district. In appreciation of their commitment to San Diego Unified, the program awards a service pin for an employee's 5, 10, 15, 20, 30 and 40 year service anniversary. This month, we are honoring individuals who celebrated a milestone in May and June.

 

In an effort to honor and feature as many employees as possible, all employees being recognized are invited to submit a self-recorded video for inclusion in the recognition portion of the board meeting. The video is also shared on the district's Employee Recognition web page. 

 

Click this link to view the AASD Distinguished Leader Video

Click this link to the May and June 2022 Employee Recognition Video

 

*This service recognition award is not used to calculate or verify the seniority date of an employee nor is the recognition part of the formal personnel processes that calculate the date for longevity pay. Both longevity and seniority dates are dictated by the Education Code as well as the applicable collective bargaining agreement. The date used to determine this service award is based on the individual's permanent status as an employee, temporary or hourly work is not used in the determination of the service award recognition. Service recognition awards will be awarded on a monthly basis. If you believe an error has been made, you may contact the Human Resource Service Division by emailing jobs@sandi.net.

 

Originator/Contact: Acacia Thede, Chief Human Resources Officer, 619.725.8043, athede@sandi.net

F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
2. Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing June 23, 2022 as Alan Turing Day (Beiser/Barrera)
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of recognizing June 23, 2022, as Alan Turing Day.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: During the month of June, San Diego Unified celebrates Pride month and recognizes the outstanding contributions of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and other non-gender conforming individuals. British mathematician Alan Turing, who was born June 23, 1912 and died June 7, 1954, was a hero of the Second World War, the founder of modern computer science and someone persecuted for his homosexuality. Turing was a brilliant mathematician, whose 1936 work “on computable numbers” laid the foundation for modern computer algorithms and the field of computer science. Turing went on to build a “universal machine,” which was in fact one of the world’s first computers. Turing also pioneered the field of developmental biology, showing how the study of algorithms could predict patterns in nature, including the seed heads on a sunflower spiral and the pattern of a leopard’s spots. Turing was also a war hero, contributing his mathematical and computing capabilities to the Allied war effort, working at the famous Bletchley Park lab and helping to break the Nazi enigma machine, shortening the war and saving millions of lives. Turing was persecuted in his lifetime for his homosexuality, facing arrest and eventually taking his own life. In England, the Alan Turning Act of 2017 officially pardoned Turing and others wrongfully prosecuted for their sexuality. Turing summarized his own work in words that capture the ongoing commitment of San Diego Unified to expand education and increase knowledge, when he said his progress was “only a foretaste of what is to come, and only the shadow of what is to be.”

 

[Originator/Contact: Kevin Beiser and Richard Barrera, Board of Education Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
3. Resolution in the Matter of LGBTQIA+ Social, Emotional, and Physical Safety (Beiser/Barrera)
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of support for LGBTQIA+ social, emotional, and physical safety. The Board of Education calls upon the Superintendent to ensure that all schools that wish to have Genders and Sexualities Alliances (GSA) and/or Rainbow groups are allowed to do so, and that those schools that already have GSAs support their student leaders; that all schools have gender-affirming safe spaces and that those spaces are made known to students and staff; that homophobia and transphobia are not tolerated on any San Diego Unified campus; that appropriate training on gender identity and sexuality be incorporated into required trainings for district staff, as required by Title IX; that all educators abide by and respect student requests for changes to their names and pronouns; that “advocacy” and “bullying prevention/intervention measures and programming” are understood by all staff, as proactive and foundational to positive and affirming school climate for all students including [but not limited to] LGBTQIA+ students; and that staff members are actively encouraged by administrators to engage their UTK-12 students in developmentally appropriate curriculum that explores the nuanced layers of diverse human identities and experiences including [but not limited to] LGBTQIA+ identities, so that students may see themselves and their families accurately and respectfully reflected in the curriculum. The Board also calls upon the Superintendent to provide information on implementation of these measures to the Board and public as part of its LCAP updates.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The San Diego Unified School District takes seriously the safety of all students, especially our most vulnerable students, which include Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer, Nonbinary and other non-gender conforming individuals. Bullying, intimidation, hate-speech and other forms of harassment are not tolerated in San Diego Unified. We seek to become better as a system, one focused on rooting out systemic inequities and ensuring a safe and welcoming environment for all students. This commitment is consistent with board action over the past decade through establishment of the Safe Schools Advisory Group; adoption of the Bullying, Harassment, and Intimidation Prohibition Policy; support for Assembly Bill 9 (Seth’s Law); establishment of a Program Manager position dedicated to LGBTQIA+ Advocacy and Education; support for Assembly Bill 493, Teachers: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer And Questioning Pupil Resources and Training; support for No Name Calling Week; partnership with the Gay Lesbian Straight Education Network (GLSEN); continued partnership with the San Diego LGBTQ Community Center to provide support services to students and faculty on district campuses; dedicating resources to LGBTQIA+ students through the Local Control and Accountability Plan (LCAP); and raising the Pride Flag at the Education Center. District leadership has worked to address all forms of bullying, harassment or intimidation; the most prominent results of these efforts have been the establishment of Genders and Sexualities Alliances (GSA) at 67 schools; and the establishment of gender-neutral restrooms and safe spaces at elementary, middle and high schools. The San Diego Unified Board of Education annually adopts Resolutions in support of Harvey Milk Day (May), LGBTQIA+ Pride Month (June) and LGBTQIA+ History Month (October). Despite the best efforts of San Diego Unified, there remains the potential that LGBTQIA+ students may continue to face persecution and ridicule or feel unsafe at school simply for being who they are.

 

[Originator/Contact: Kevin Beiser and Richard Barrera, Board of Education Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

1. Propositions S, Z and Measure YY Updates to the Board of Education, Construction Bond Project Plan and Resolution in the Matter of Approving Revised Propositions S, Z and Measure YY Plan; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No

RECOMMENDATION: Approve revised Propositions S, Z and Measure YY Bond Program Plan and adopt resolution approving revised Propositions S, Z and Measure YY project plan and projects undertaken pursuant to Propositions S, Z and Measure YY as shown on Attachment 1.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: $500,873,896 for Fiscal Year 2020-21.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Ongoing. The Independent Citizens' Oversight Committee met on May 19, 2022. 

 

BACKGROUND: This update addresses project milestones and provides an overview of the current program. On November 4, 2008, November 6, 2012, and November 6, 2018, voters approved, respectively, Propositions S, Z and Measure YY general obligation bond measures to improve every school in the San Diego Unified School District. On May 14, 2013, the Board of Education (Board) approved the Proposition Z Two-Year Project Plan for implementing projects identified in the Bond Project List and included estimated project schedules. On December 1, 2013, the Board approved an update to the Proposition Z Two-Year Project Plan which also incorporated Proposition S projects and schedules. On June 3, 2014, Propositions S and Z Project Plan expanded beyond its two-year time horizon and has come to be known as the multiple-year project plan. The multiple-year project plan has subsequently been updated at each staff presentation to the Board, most recently on December 7, 2021. In response to Board priorities and direction, staff is presenting its latest update to the multiple-year project plan for Board approval which includes references to the voter guides for Proposition S, Proposition Z, and Measure YY projects.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

Subject
2. Independent Citizens' Oversight Committee (ICOC) for Propositions S and Z and Measure YY, Semi-Annual Update to the Board; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: Receive report from the Propositions S, Z and Measure YY Independent Citizens' Oversight Committee (ICOC).  ICOC Chair Andy Berg and Vice Chair, Rajali Walker, will present the Committee's semi-annual update to the Board of Education addressing these topics:

  • ICOC Responsibilities & Activities
  • Review Expenditures
  • Inspection of Bond Funded Projects
  • Financial and Performance Audit Review

 

BACKGROUND: Proposition S, a $2.1 billion general obligation bond measure, was approved by the voters on November 4, 2008. On November 6, 2012, Proposition Z, a $2.8 billion general obligation bond measure was approved by voters. On November 6, 2018, Measure YY, a $3.5 billion general obligation bond measure was approved by voters.

 

The Independent Citizens’ Oversight Committee was established to ensure Propositions S, Z and Measure YY funds are properly expended; review Propositions S, Z amd Measure YY financial audits; review district deferred maintenance plans; and review district efforts to maximize Propositions S, Z and Measure YY revenues.

 

[Originator/Contact: ICOC Chair Andy Berg, icoc@sandi.net]

Subject
3. Independent Citizens Oversight Committee on Racial Justice and Equity: Update to the Board
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: This item is presented for information only. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: The Independent Citizens' Oversight Committee on Racial Justice and Equity prepared this presentation on June 8, 2022 during its regularly scheduled meeting.

 

BACKGROUND: The Independent Citizens' Oversight Committee on Racial Justice and Equity holds the San Diego Unified School District accountable to the public on whether we are making progress in the following areas:

  • Interrupting Discriminatory Grading Practices
  • Dismantling Discriminatory Discipline Policies and Practices
  • Implementation of Ethnic Studies for All Students
  • Transformation of School Police
  • Staff Diversity

Per the Board of Education's direction on July 21, 2020, the Committee will have analyzed data that is necessary to monitor progress and report back to the public and make recommendations. The Committee will annually report whether or not the district is making progress. For the 2022 calendar year, the ICOC will receive a staff report and will also hear from a student focus group who will share their lived experiences on our campuses. Each focus group will address one of the five areas of focus for this committee. The combination of data and student voice will assist the committee in its duties in reporting to the Board.

H. District Operations
Subject
1. First Reading and Public Hearing of the Proposed 2022-23 Local Control Accountability Plan
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information, Public Hearing

RECOMMENDATION: Conduct a public hearing and first reading of the district's proposed 2022-23 Local Control and Accountability Plan (LCAP). This plan represents year 2 of the District's 3-year plan. A workshop was conducted on June 8, 2022, at which the Superintendent and staff provided information to the board and the public on the implementation of the Local Control Accountability Plan in year one and next steps moving forward into year 2. Each goal was reviewed, and plans for implementation of each goal in the 2022-23 school year were presented. The proposed 2022-23 LCAP will be presented to the Board of Education for final reading and adoption on June 28, 2022. Included in this years LCAP is the Supplemental Report that was presented to the board February 2022. In addition to the full LCAP document, the district's Local Indicators results are included with this item. These results will be entered in the California Dashboard system later this year and reported as part of the state Dashboard release in December.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: The proposed 2022-23 LCAP is submitted for first reading in conjunction with the first reading of the proposed 2022-23 budget.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: The Annual Update section of the proposed 2022-23 LCAP includes 2021-22 actions, services, and estimated actual expenditures.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: The District Advisory Council (DAC) and the District English Learner Advisory Committee (DELAC) serve as the district's LCAP advisory committees. During 2021-22, 11 updates on LCAP implementation were presented to the board and public at regular board meetings including:
Goal 1: Social Emotional Learning & Mental Health (Nov. 2021), Restorative Practices (Jan. 2022), Wellness (May 2022)
Goal 2: Assessment & Standards Based Reporting (Oct. 2021), On-Track to Graduation (March 2022)
Goal 3: Extended Learning (Sept. 2021), Universal TK (March 2022) Literacy Acceleration Plan (May 2022), 
Goal 4: E3 - Growth and Development (May 2022), TEACH-LEAD Program Implementation (June 2022)
Goal 5: Families as Partners (March 2022)
Goal 6: Increased Communication (April 2022)

Presentations were then replicated at the DAC meetings to receive additional input/feedback. The early draft 2022-23 LCAP was made available on the District's websites and information sessions were held with the DAC on March 16th, April 20th, and May 18th and to the DELAC on March 3rd, April 7th, and May 5th for review and comment. The full document is posted on the district website at https://www.sandiegounified.org/about/local_control_and_accountability_plan/what_is_the_lcap.

 

BACKGROUND: The LCAP is intended to be a comprehensive planning tool. For school districts, pursuant to Education Code Section 52060, the LCAP must describe, for the school district and each school within the district, goals and specific actions to achieve those goals for all students and each subgroup of students in Education Code Section 52052, including students with disabilities, for each of the state priorities and any locally identified priorities. A new addition to the LCAP this year is Goal 7, Strategic Support for Designated Schools. 

 

The district's LCAP Goals are:

  1. Cultivating Inclusive Anti-Racist, and Restorative Schools, Classrooms & District - with Equity at the Core and Support for the Whole Child. 
  2. Access to Broad and Challenging Curriculum
  3. Accelerating Learning with High Expectations for All
  4. Quality Leadership, Teaching and Learning
  5. Family and Community Engagement with Highly Regarded Neighborhood Schools that Serve Students, Families, and Communities
  6. Well-Orchestrated Districtwide Support Services and Communications
  7. Strategic Support for Designated Schools

 

[Originator/Contact: Dr. Lamont A. Jackson, Superintendent, 619-725-5506]

H. District Operations
Subject
2. Public Hearing of the 2022-23 Annual Service and Budget Plan for the Local Plan for Special Education
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Public Hearing

RECOMMENDATION: Conduct a public hearing the 2022-23 Annual Service and Budget Plan for the Local Plan for Special Education.


FISCAL IMPACT: None.


PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.


IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.


CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: The Community Advisory Committee (CAC)
for Special Education reviewed the plan on June 9, 2022.


BACKGROUND: This certification is required by the California Department of Education (CDE) on an
annual basis prior to the year in which the budget is adopted. The Annual Budget Plan identifies
revenues and expenditures for all items required under Education Code Section 56205, which identifies
the following:


A. Revenue: Funds received from Federal, State and Local sources to support the Special Education
Program.


B. Expenditures: Administrative costs of the plan, special education services to students with severe
disabilities and low incidence disabilities, special education services to students with non-severe
disabilities, supplemental aids and services to meet the individual needs of students placed in general
education classrooms, and the use of property taxes allocated to the SELPA.


The Services Descriptors of the Annual Service Plan are a description of services provided by the Special
Education Local Plan Area (SELPA) to individuals with exceptional needs. Pursuant to Education
Code Section 56205(B)(2), these service descriptors demonstrate that all individuals, age birth through
21 years, with exceptional needs have access to services and instruction appropriate to meet their
needs as currently specified in their Individual Education Programs.


Pursuant to CDE requirements, Certification of the Annual Budget Plan and Service Descriptors shall be
submitted to CDE by June 30, 2022. In accordance with the CDE's requirement, and Annual Service
Location Plan based on the codes in the Service Descriptors will also be submitted to CDE by June 30,
2022.


[Originator/Contact: Ed Baisley, Director, Special Education, 619.725.7389, ebaisley@sandi.net]

Subject
4. Resolution Authorizing Issuance and Sale of 2022-23 Tax and Revenue Anticipation Notes (TRANs) in Amount Not to Exceed $280,000,000 and Authorizing Execution and Delivery of Documents Related Thereto; BUDGETED: YES, TAX AND REVENUE ANTICIPATION NOTES (TRANs)
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Tax and Revenue Anticipation Notes (TRANs)

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt Resolution authorizing the 2022-23 Tax and Revenue Anticipation Notes (TRANS) in an amount not to exceed $280,000,000.00 and authorize the execution and delivery of related documents, including a Note Purchase Agreement, Preliminary Official Statement/Official Statement, Continuing Disclosure Certificate-an exhibit to the Preliminary Official Statement at Appendix D, and a Fiscal Agent Agreement; the forms of which are attached and incorporated to this item. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: The cost of borrowing is mitigated by interest earned on TRANs proceeds while on deposit prior to withdrawal. The average annual yield to maturity for the quarter ending March 31, 2022, in the San Diego County Investment Pool was 0.642 percent, but the district may invest proceeds outside of the County's Investment Pool to the extent that additional interest may be earned thereon.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Board of Education has annually adopted a resolution for issuance of TRANs for the upcoming fiscal year, most recently at the June 22, 2021 meeting for the 2021-22 fiscal year. Budget String: 5528-00006-00-5840-9100-0000-01000-0000.

 

The district receives a substantial portion of its annual income from property taxes, which are traditionally paid by taxpayers on or before December 10 or April 10. As a result, the district must borrow funds each year in advance of these dates to pay operational expenses in the July to December timeframe. Thus, funds are borrowed at the beginning of the fiscal year using TRANs notes and repaid within an eight to twelve month period. Short-term borrowing using TRANs is necessary to ensure the district meets its financial obligations on a cash basis.

 

On March 22, 2022, the Board approved a pool of firms to provide financial underwriting services to support the sale of Propositions S, Z and Measure YY bonds and TRANs issuances. The district has annually utilized this approved pool of firms from which to select the Underwriters that will purchase and sell the district's annual TRANs. On March 23, 2022, the district solicited proposals from the firms in the approved pool of providers for the 2022-23 TRANs issuance. The proposals were reviewed by the district’s financial advisor, KNN Public Finance, LLC, as well as members of the district’s Finance Division. Upon completion of the review of the proposals submitted, Citigroup Global Markets, Inc. and Siebert Williams Shank & Co., LLC were elected to provide underwriting services for the 2022-23 TRANs and will be written into the Resolution.

 

[Originator/Contact: Alicia Rolfe, Controller, Finance Division, 619.725.7171, arolfe@sandi.net]

Subject
5. Resolution Authorizing Projected Debt Service Schedule For Proposition S Bonds, Proposition Z Bonds and Measure YY Bonds of San Diego Unified School District And Authorizing The Taking Of Necessary Actions Relating Thereto; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt a resolution in the matter of authorizing projected debt service schedule for Proposition S Bonds, Proposition Z Bonds and Measure YY Bonds of San Diego Unified School District and authorizing the taking of necessary actions relating thereto.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: At an election held on November 4, 2008 the district sought authorization under Proposition S to issue general obligation bonds in an amount of up to $2.1 billion. Proposition S was approved by more than 55 percent of the district's eligible voters voting on the proposition. Proceeds from the sale of bonds (the "Proposition S Bonds") are to be used by the district for the specific school facilities projects set forth in Proposition S. 

 

A Memorandum of Understanding between the district and County of San Diego, dated June 1, 2019, was executed with respect to establishing a combined annual reserve for bonds issued under Proposition S and Proposition MM, authorized by voters within the district on November 3, 1998, for the purpose of avoiding a fluctuating tax levy in accordance with Section 15250 of the Education Code. A projected debt service schedule for the Proposition S Bonds to be issued this year has been provided to assist the County in determining the tax levy and its uses for this fiscal year.

 

At an election held on November 6, 2012 the district sought authorization under Proposition Z to issue general obligation bonds in an amount of up to $2.8 billion. Proposition Z was approved by more than 55 percent of the district's eligible voters voting on the proposition. Proceeds from the sale of bonds (the "Proposition Z Bonds") are to be used by the district for the specific school facilities projects set forth in Proposition Z. 

 

A Memorandum of Understanding between the district and County of San Diego, dated June 1, 2019, was executed with respect to establishing an annual reserve for bonds issued under Proposition Z for the purpose of avoiding a fluctuating tax levy in accordance with Section 15250 of the Education Code. A projected debt service schedule for the Proposition Z Bonds to be issued this year has been provided to assist the County in determining the tax levy and its uses for this fiscal year.

 

At an election held on November 6, 2018 the district sought authorization under Measure YY to issue general obligation bonds in an amount of up to $3.5 billion. Measure YY was approved by more than 55 percent of the district's eligible voters voting on the proposition. Proceeds from the sale of bonds (the "Measure YY Bonds") are to be used by the district for the specific school facilities projects set forth in Measure YY. 

 

A Memorandum of Understanding between the district and County of San Diego, dated June 1, 2019, was executed with respect to establishing an annual reserve for bonds issued under Measure YY for the purpose of avoiding a fluctuating tax levy in accordance with Section 15250 of the Education Code. A projected debt service schedule for the Measure YY Bonds to be issued this year has been provided to assist the County in determining the tax levy and its uses for this fiscal year.

 

 

 

[Originator/Contact: Alicia Rolfe, Controller, Finance Division, 619.725.7171, arolfe@sandi.net]

REQUIRES 4 VOTES.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The current water meter serves Morse High School, and is located in the right of way.  This easement (Attachment 2) is being requested and is required to expand the area to meet City design guide standards for clearance and access to the facility for service and maintenance.

 

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the proposed resolution of intent to grant the City a permanent easement and right-of-way for water facilities at Morse High School is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et seq, and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et seq, as amended). On November 12, 2019, the board approved a CEQA Notice of Exemption for the Morse High School Whole Site Modernization Project, which included the installation of a water pipeline on a portion of District property consistent with the subject easement. The board also directed staff to file the Notice of Exemption for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County which was completed on November 13, 2019 (Attachment 3). Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that approval of the resolution of intent is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the referenced NOE, and no further CEQA review is required.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

3. First Amendment to Agreement with National Conflict Resolution Center to Continue Implementing the Districtwide Restorative Protocols and Processes in Alignment with the District’s Restorative Discipline Program; BUDGETED: YES, TITLE I BASIC PROGRAM
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$15,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
TITLE I BASIC PROGRAM

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify First Amendment to Agreement with National Conflict Resolution Center to add trainings specific to only Monroe Clark Middle School and to continue implementing the districtwide restorative protocols and processes in alignment with the district’s Restorative Discipline Program (PS22-0178-25). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this First Amendment. The term of the Agreement is unchanged (August 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022).

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $15,000.00 is added by this First Amendment to Agreement, for a new total not-to-exceed amount of $234,539.00. Budget String: 0322-30100-00-5853-1000-1110-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of November 4, 2021 through June 3, 2022: $219,539.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On September 28, 2021 the board ratified the Agreement with National Conflict Resolution Center to continue implementing the districtwide restorative protocols and processes in alignment with the district’s Restorative Discipline Program. The term of this Agreement is August 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022.

 

The First Amendment will add to the Scope of Work offering trainings specific to only Monroe Clark Middle School and increase the total not-to-exceed amount by $15,000.00 for a new not-to-exceed total of $234,539.00.

 

National Conflict Resolution Center (NCRC) will continue to support the district in developing capacity at school sites by implementing the restorative protocols and processes aligned with its Restorative Discipline Program (RDP).  This NCRC Program promotes a shared understanding, builds healing systems, and repairs harm when it occurs to students on school campuses.

 

This RDP helps students and staff embody the principles of safety, responsibility, respectfulness, appreciation of differences, honesty, and lifelong learning.  It also helps to assess and apply the appropriate levels of interventions and discipline practices to effectively support the implementation of this program.

 

This program continues from the previous Agreement (PS21-0465-25) with professional development and training customized to support students by coaching and developing coping and communication skills.  These early interventions provide students with an alternative to suspension or expulsion.

 

[Originator/Contact: Christina Casillas, Area 3 Superintendent, 619.725.5602, ccasillas2@sandi.net]

5. Second Amendment to Agreement with Joy Raab to Continue Providing Expressive Art Therapy to District Students with Disabilities; BUDGETED: YES; TITLE I SUPPLEMENTAL PROGRAM IMPROVEMENT FUNDS
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$30,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Title I Supplement Program Improvement Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Second Amendment to Agreement with Joy Raab to continue providing expressive art therapy to district students with disabilities (PS19-0096-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this service. The new term of this Agreement is July 18, 2018 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $30,000.00 is added by this Second Amendment to Agreement, for a new total not-to-exceed amount of $130,000.00. Budget String: 0479-30106-00-5150-1000-1110-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 16, 2020 through July 22, 2021: $59,121.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On September 4, 2018, the board ratified the Agreement with Joy Raab to provide expressive art therapy to district students with disabilities. The term of the original Agreement was July 1, 2018 through June 30, 2020.

 

On April 14, 2020 the board approved the First Amendment to continue providing expressive art therapy services to district students with disabilities and added $60,000.00, for a new total not-to-exceed of $100,000.00, and two years to the original Agreement, revising the term to July 1, 2018 through June 30, 2022.

 

This Second Amendment will allow the Joy Raab to continue providing expressive art therapy to district students with disabilities. In addition, it extends the term by one year for a new term of July 1, 2018 through June 30, 2023, and increases the Agreement by $30,000.00 for a new total not-to-exceed of amount $130,000.00.

 

Joy Raab is an Independent Activity Coordinator who provides expressive arts programs for all ages and abilities. Expressive art therapy augments support for students with communication and mental health needs. Ms. Raab uses the five disciplines of the arts: dance/movement, music, drama/theater, visual and writing/poetry as a way for students in the Special Education Transition Resources for Adult/Community Education (TRACE) school to communicate by developing social skills including deepening of peer relationships and identification of feelings and emotions. Ms. Raab instructs and leads students with special needs in various activities and techniques designed to meet specific and/or psychological needs. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Erin Richison, Area 6 Superintendent, 619.725.5584 erichison@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION:  Approve Agreement with UMASS Global to provide on-site learning and supervision opportunities for school counseling fieldwork students in graduate training programs on behalf of the Counseling and Guidance Department (PS23-0023-25).  Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement.  The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2027.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district will partner with UMASS Global to provide on-site learning and supervision opportunities for school counseling fieldwork students in graduate training programs.

 

The district’s Counseling and Guidance staff will assign the universities’ graduate students placements at school sites.  Counseling fieldwork students will receive on-site learning, supervision, and contact hours for their credentialing.  The university students will provide services to the district’s students as part of their learning experience, supporting the district students with their academic development, personal/social development, and career planning.

 

Finally, this on-site intern instructional program provides the university students with service hours while pursuing their Pupil Personnel Services credentials as required by the California Commission on Teacher Credentialing (CCTC) regulations and standards.

 

This on-site counseling fieldwork program demonstrates the continued commitment to school counselors and higher education by teaching and mentoring possible future school counselors in the San Diego community.

RECOMMENDATION:  Approve First Amendment to Agreement with TEKsystems Global Services, LLC, to continue providing districtwide Covid-19 contact tracing and software support services on behalf of the Nursing and Wellness Department (SV22-0486-36).  Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this First Amendment. The revised term of the Agreement is September 30, 2021 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT:  The total not-to-exceed amount: $5,106,800.00 is being added by this First Amendment, for a new total not-to-exceed amount of $10,213,600.00.  Budget String: 5400-32131-00-5100-1000-1110-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT:  For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $2,150,037.93.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  On October 12, 2021, the board ratified an Agreement with TEKsystems Global Services, LLC, on behalf of the Nursing and Wellness Department to provide Covid-19 contact tracing software support for district students and staff.

 

This First Amendment to Agreement adds $5,106,800.00 to the Agreement and extends the term through June 30, 2023 to continue providing experts in Covid-19 contact tracing and software support services for the district.  Funds provided under the CARES Act will support the implementation of public health protocols for these testing services.

 

The Nursing and Wellness Department does not have sufficient staff to support the district’s students in providing the Covid-19 contact tracing and to report status to the governing agencies.  Allowable under Elementary and Secondary Emergency Relief (ESSER) through supporting implementation of public health protocols via testing and support services.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Susan Barndollar, Executive Director, Nursing and Wellness, 619.725.5501, sbarndollar@sandi.net]

ICC recommendations are based on the following criteria: (1) clear correlation to state academic standards; (2) an evaluation plan to judge the efficacy of the pilot course; (3) applicable fulfillment of University of California a-g requirements; and (4) accordance with state education code provisions.

 

The ICC met via Zoom on May 18, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Any costs associated with the proposed site adopted courses will be supported by the site.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

                                                                                                

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE:  Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  The ICC is responsible for the assessment and recommendation of requests pertaining to the curriculum included in the district Course of Study.  The ICC reviews and recommends new courses, deletion of courses, and changes to approved courses to the Board of Education. It ensures that all courses are rigorous and provide students with multiple pathways to graduation, college, and career. Revisions to the course of study are aligned with LCAP Goal 2.3.a.  The Committee is composed of the following members who are elected from among their peers, as stipulated by By-Laws that were adopted in September 2019:

 

  • 50 percent school site personnel, including two high school principals, two middle school principals, one other administrator.

 

  • 50 percent central office personnel: four program managers and one director.

Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.

Action (Consent)

Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Instructional Technology Title I Basic Program Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Tools for Schools, Inc., to provide online book libraries for district teachers to embed in their curriculum (SW23-0188-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The initial term of this Agreement is August 1, 2022 through July 31, 2023, with the delegation of authority to the Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Officer to exercise additional four one-year options to renew, subject to the identification of a budgeted funding source.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount for initial term: $75,000.00.  Budget String: 5434-30100-00-5841-1000-1110-01000-0000.

Total not-to-exceed amount for option year 1: $82,500.00. Budget String will be determined at a later date if option is exercised. 

Total not-to-exceed amount for option year 2: $90,750.00. Budget String will be determined at a later date if option is exercised.

Total not-to-exceed amount for option year 3: $99,825.00. Budget String will be determined at a later date if option is exercised.

Total not-to-exceed amount for option year 4: $105,600.00. Budget String will be determined at a later date if option is exercised.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Approval of this Agreement will provide every teacher with the ability to create unlimited libraries (with 200 books in each). This will provide the scope for teachers to embed Book Creator across their curriculum and use it for projects, homework, class activities, reports and journals across subject areas. The ability to create libraries gives teachers the flexibility to publish libraries for classes and for individual lesson plans, to share with other teachers, and even with other schools or parents. Teachers also have the option to give students their own libraries to create portfolios of work. Teachers can work together to support students, share ideas, book templates, and be inspired by each other’s work. This also gives Technology Integration teams an oversight of how Book Creator is being used, as well as the ability to easily provide support and coaching. Students can collaborate on books at the same time across multiple devices, allowing teachers to assign group projects and team-based learning.

 

[Originator/Contact: Wendy Ranck-Buhr, Instructional Support Officer, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.5678, wranck-buhr@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Approve the 2022-23 California Interscholastic Federation (CIF) league representatives for Coordinating Council for San Diego Unified School District Schools. The representatives for San Diego Unified School District are: Jason Babineau, Hoover High; Francisca Del Carmen, San Diego High; and Scott Giusti, PE Health & Athletics Department. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The CIF requires each school district of every league in the state to annually designate their league representatives. San Diego Unified School District's Athletic Council nominated and elected the representatives. The designated league representatives must be approved by the school district and/or their governing board.  

 

California Education Code section 33353(a)(1), requires that the boards, after joining CIF, designate their representatives to CIF Leagues. The representatives of boards are the only persons who make recommendations to the CIF Board of Managers, at the league and section levels, that affect athletics. Upon approval of this agenda item, San Diego Unified School District CIF representatives to the League will be Jason Babineau, Hoover High; Francisca Del Carmen, San Diego High; and Scott Giusti, Director of PE, Health & Athletics. The City Conference President will be the City Conference CIF representative to the League. Selection process of representatives is voluntary.  

 

[Originator/Contact: Scott Giusti, Director of Interscholastic Athletics, APE, ASB, JROTC, PE & SHEP, 619.725.7126, sgiusti@sandi.net]

19. Agreement with California State University San Marcos, Department of Speech-Language Pathology to Provide Consultation, Collaboration, Speech and Language Assessment, and Speech and Language Services to District Students; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with California State University San Marcos, Department of Speech-Language Pathology to provide consultation, collaboration, speech and language assessment, and speech and language services to district students (PS23-0119-37). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2027.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: CSU San Marcos (University) provides high-quality Speech-Language Pathology (SLP) Interns who support district students identified as needing speech and language services through their Individual Education Plan (IEP). During their internship, they receive training in district Best Practices supporting students with special needs. The result of the collaboration results in hiring well-trained and highly qualified SLPs who support students with special needs in the district using Best Practices as adopted by the district. These highly qualified SLPs are more independent and effective in delivering required speech and language services to district students. They are also skilled in assessing students with diverse backgrounds and making appropriate eligibility decisions. The University shall ensure that the University students model behavior in accordance with professional and ethical practices for the profession of speech-language pathology, and the University and/or University students will perform responsibilities under the direct supervision of district SLP staff.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreements with Multiple Providers to Provide Speech-Language Pathology Services to Students with Identified or Suspected Special Needs as Specified in their Individual Education Plan (IEP) and Mandated Under State and Federal Special Education Laws. Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate these Agreements. The term of these Agreements is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2027.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $2,700,000.00. Budget String: 5380-65000-00-5160-1190-5770-01000-4530

 

(PS23-0098-37) Sound Therapies, Inc.: $1,500,000.00

(PS23-0099-37) Pioneer Healthcare Services, LLC: $600,000.00

(PS23-0134-37) New Direction Solutions, LLC dba ProCare Therapy: $600,000.00

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: These providers will provide Speech-Language Pathology services to students with special needs as mandated under State and Federal special education laws. The district does not have sufficient staff to provide speech-language pathology services to district students with identified or suspected special needs as specified in their Individualized Education Plan (IEP). The district will establish a pool of qualified speech-language pathologists from these providers, to meet the needs of students. The district is required to contract with outside agencies to provide Speech and Language services due to district employees taking leave for the following reasons: family leaves, short-term leaves, and long-term leaves. 

 

California Government Code 53060 grants the district the authority to contract with and employ persons for the furnishing of special services if such persons are specially trained, experienced, and competent to perform the special services required.

RECOMMENDATION: Approve expulsion of the students discussed in Closed Session and in accordance with the recommendations of the staff. These students will be expelled and will be required to complete a specific plan of rehabilitation. This plan may include, but not necessarily be limited to, counseling, employment, community service, making restitution, making appropriate apologies, and completing other rehabilitative programs.

26. The Learning Choice Academy: Material Revision to Remove a Site From the Charter Petition
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)

RECOMMENDATION:  Approve the proposed revision to the charter of The Learning Choice Academy to remove a location at 9950 Scripps Lake Drive, San Diego, 92131, effective July 1, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Learning Choice Academy (“TLC”) is operated by the nonprofit public benefit corporation of the same name, pursuant to Education Code section 47604.  TLC’s charter petition was renewed on April 9, 2019, for a five-year term beginning July 1, 2019, and ending June 30, 2024. Per Assembly Bill 130, TLC’s charter term was extended by two years, and will now end on June 30, 2026.  The following table summarizes the charter petition, renewals, and extension.

 

Table 1: Summary of Charter Petition and Renewals

Item

TLC Extension

July 9, 2021 (AB 130)

July 1, 2024 – June 30, 2026

 

TLC is a nonclassroom-based charter school that offers a variety of options for students.  Families can choose a 100 percent homeschool option, or a hybrid program which offers on-site learning for two or three days per week.

 

Through the end of the 2017-18 school year, TLC operated four resource center sites (Scripps Ranch, Temecula, La Mesa, and Chula Vista) under the district-authorized charter.  As of July 1, 2018, TLC, in compliance with the Anderson v. Shasta ruling, transitioned the charter authorization of its Chula Vista site to the Chula Vista Elementary School District.  As of July 1, 2019, TLC transitioned the charter authorization of its La Mesa site to the Grossmont Union High School District.  On or about September 1, 2019, TLC voluntarily closed its Temecula site.

 

Under the district-authorized charter, TLC currently serves Grades K-12 from the following two locations:

 

  • 9950 Scripps Lake Drive, Suites 104 and 105 (Scripps Ranch)
  • 4635 Clairemont Mesa Boulevard (Clairemont)

RENEWAL VERSUS REVISION:

A petition to open a new charter school can be approved by the district for up to a five-year term.  Near the end of the term, a charter school applies for “renewal” of its charter to continue operating.[1]  Education Code section 47605 requires the review and approval process for new and renewing charter petitions to take place over two board meetings: (i) public hearing, and (ii) action to grant/deny.

 

Within a charter term, a charter school may request the district’s approval to revise its existing charter.  Pursuant to Education Code section 47607, material revisions are governed by the standards and criteria described in Education Code section 47605, and may be made only with the approval of the authority that granted the charter.

 

FACILITY CONSIDERATIONS:

TLC took the following factors into consideration in deciding to remove the Scripps Ranch location as an operating site:

 

  • The rental rate on the Scripps Ranch site was going to triple beginning July 1.
  • While the facility was adequate, it was not optimally set up to serve as an educational setting, as highlighted by the pandemic.
  • The fire marshal was requiring a significant amount of upgrades to the facility, and the landlord expected the school to pay for them.
  • The Clairemont site offers several facility components that Scripps Ranch does not, including a gymnasium, cafeteria, STEM lab, and outside spaces.
  • TLC has a three-year lease for the Clairemont facility, beginning August 1, 2021, and ending July 31, 2024.

 

TLC currently has a total of 168 students enrolled.  There are 75 students in the 100 percent homeschool program, and 93 students attending the hybrid programs at the Clairemont site.  The Clairemont site has enough space to accommodate the total current enrollment.  The facility allows the school to offer its supporting services to students, including but not limited to, testing, growing CTE programs, tutoring, wet labs, counseling services (individual and small group), special education services, study groups, and teacher-student meetings.

FINANCIAL REVIEW:

TLC’s Second Interim Report included a board approved revised budget from March 8, 2022.  The charter is projecting to end the year with an operating deficit of ($165,582), however, the ending fund balance of $2,643,388 has enough to cover the deficit.  As of January 31, 2022, the school had enough cash ($2,541,253.00) to cover total liabilities of $93,750.00.  The school had over 3 percent in reserves for Economic Uncertainty.  The budget approved on March 8, 2022, was based on ADA of 169.54 which is in line with Fiscal Year 2021-22 P2 ADA of 169.45.  The budget includes one-time ESSER III and ELO funds.

 

The lease for Scripps Ranch is $11,851.00/month. By not renewing the lease, the school will decrease total expenditures for the year by $142,212.00 with an additional estimated $15,000.00 in utilities. Minimizing rent expenditures will have a beneficial impact on TLC’s financials.  There will be no increase in the lease amount for the Clairemont site.

CONCLUSION:

Grant the proposed revision to the charter of The Learning Choice Academy to remove a location at 9950 Scripps Lake Drive, San Diego, 92131, effective July 1, 2022.

 

[1] Per California Education Code sections 47607 and 47607.2, a charter renewal term may be for two years, five years, or five to seven years, depending on whether the school is considered low performing, middle performing, or high performing.

[2] Some of the declines reported on the Dashboard may be due to the changes in historic enrollment and operational structure at TLC.  As detailed in this report, TLC moved two of its larger out-of-district sites that had been operating under the district-approved charter to the local authorizers (Grossmont and Chula vista) to comply with the Andersen ruling.

[3] Enrollment for the 2024-25 and 2025-26 school years was not submitted by the charter school.  Based on the two year renewal extension provided by Assembly Bill 130 (signed into law July 9, 2021), the district carried the most recent year of approved enrollment out to these years.

27. Resolution on Education Protection Account (EPA) Requirements and 2021-22 EPA Program by Resource Report; REVENUE: EDUCATION PROTECTION ACCOUNT (EPA)
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$19,572,744.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Revenue: Education Protection Account (EPA)

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt Resolution on the Education Protection Account (EPA) Requirements and the 2021-22 EPA Program by Resource Report in accordance with the Proposition 30 requirement that the use of EPA Funds are determined by the governing board at an open public meeting.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: $19,572,744.00.  Revenue Budget String: 0000-14000-00-8012-0000-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Proposition 30, the Schools and Local Public Safety Protection Act of 2012, approved by the voters on November 6, 2012, temporarily increases the state's sales tax rate for all taxpayers and the personal income tax rates for upper-income taxpayers.

 

The new revenues generated from Proposition 30 are deposited into a newly-created state account called the Education Protection Account (EPA). School districts, county offices of education, and charter schools (Local Education Agencies or LEAs) will receive funds from the EPA based on their proportionate share of the statewide revenue limit amount, which includes charter school general purpose funding.

 

A corresponding reduction was made to an LEA's revenue limit or charter school general purpose state aid equal to the amount of their EPA entitlement. For 2012-13, LEAs received EPA payments at the end of June 2013. Beginning with the 2013-14 fiscal year, LEAs received these EPA payments on a quarterly basis which commenced in September 2013.

 

Proposition 30 requires all districts, counties, and charter schools to report on their websites an accounting of how much money was received from the EPA, how that money was spent, and that the board acknowledge that the EPA funds will not be spent on administrators or other administrative costs. Proposition 30 also requires that the use of EPA funds be determined by the governing board at an open public meeting prior to any expenditures being recorded for 2021-22.

 

[Originator/Contact: Zandy Macasinag, Director, Budget Development, Finance Division, 619.725.7597, amacasinag@sandi.net]

BACKGROUND: The Jodee Blanco Group will conduct anti-bullying presentations for kindergarten to 12th grade students at up to 14 private schools for the benefit of the San Diego Catholic Diocese. Jodee Blanco is a survivor, expert, and activist. She is one of the country’s most trusted voices on the subject of bullying. A chronicle of her painful school years, the book was a cultural catalyst and helped victims of all ages reclaim their lives and dignity.

 

The district, as fiscal agent of Title IV Part A private school equitable share funding, will facilitate this Agreement for services to be provided by The Jodee Blanco Group to the Catholic Diocese of San Diego.

38. Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement with Balfour Beatty Construction Company to Provide Preconstruction Services for the Kavod Charter School Whole Site Modernization Project (Lease-Leaseback); BUDGETED: YES, MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$398,033.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement with Balfour Beatty Construction Company to provide preconstruction services for the Kavod Charter School Whole Site Modernization Project (Lease-Leaseback) CC22-0981-23. The term of this Agreement is effective June 21, 2022 and continues until the project is complete. The preconstruction services for the Kavod Charter School Whole Site Modernization Project will complete the construction design and Division of the State Architects (DSA) approved plans and specifications and will be bid out to subcontractors by Balfour Beatty Construction Company. District staff will submit amended Agreements to the Board for the construction of the project, which will include the total guaranteed maximum price (GMP) for the Agreements.  

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed Preconstruction Services: $398,033.00. Budget String: 9796-90502-00-6230-8500-0000-21500-8XXX.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On November 10, 2020, the board adopted a resolution for procedures for evaluating the qualifications of lease-leaseback contractors and the issuance of a request to prequalify for Group G, which are projects at or above $26,000,001.00 in estimated value. On November 12, 2020, the district issued a Request to Prequalify and for Statements of Qualification for Preliminary and Construction Services (RFQ) for Group G Lease-Leaseback Projects.

 

On December 17, 2020, 16 contractors submitted Statements of Qualifications (SOQs) to the district’s RFQ. After evaluating each of the SOQs under the established criteria and procedures, district staff determined that nine of the contractors met the requirements of the RFQ for Group G Projects. From those nine qualified contractors, the district issued a subsequent Request for Proposal ("RFP") for Preconstruction Services for the Kavod Charter School project, utilizing the lease-leaseback delivery method under Education Code section 17406 et seq. The best value criteria for scoring proposals included, but was not limited to demonstrated competence, relevant experience, compensation, timeliness, and staffing capacity to perform the required work.

 

Sealed proposals to the RFP were due and received on May 13, 2022. The district received three proposals from Balfour Beatty Construction Company, SOLPAC Construction, Inc., dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company, and Swinerton Builders, Inc. 

 

Based on the strengths of the proposals submitted, Balfour Beatty Construction Company has been determined to provide the best value to the district. Balfour Beatty Construction Company is deemed a responsive and responsible proposer for this project, which is located at Kavod Charter School, 6991 Balboa Ave., San Diego CA, 92111. 

 

The existing Building at Kavod Charter School was originally constructed in 1961.  There are six portable classrooms, one portable teacher's work room, one portable restroom, and eight relocatable classrooms on site.  The Main Building and site have received minor improvements since the original construction with many systems at the end of their useful life. The Kavod Charter School Project was recommended to the Board of Education, by the Charter School Facilities Committee and approved by the board on September 10, 2019.  The project includes modernization of the existing building, removal of all portable and relocatable buildings, construction of a new two-story middle school building, a new two-story elementary school building, a new multipurpose building to accommodate middle school students, and site improvements.

 

Kavod Charter School occupies the eastern campus of Clairemont Canyons Academy site, which occupies the Western portion of the site.

 

Once the Division of the State Architects (DSA) approves plans and specifications, Balfour Beatty Construction Company will bid out the construction to subcontractors. District staff will submit amended agreements to the Board for the construction of the Project, which will increase the total guaranteed maximum price for the Agreements and include the mandatory DVBE percentage requirement.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the proposed Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended). On May 15, 2018, the board approved a Final Mitigated Negative Declaration (MND) for the Clairemont Canyons Elementary School (Formerly Lindbergh Schweitzer Elementary School) Whole Site Modernization and Joint Use Field Project (Proposed Project). Addendum 1 included specific changes to the previously approved project to include the minor expansion and modernization of the Kavod Charter School. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the proposed Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the above referenced MND and Addendum, and no further CEQA review is required.

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the Re-Roof Project at Audeo Charter School is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 - Existing Facilities; and Approve Agreement with Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction to re-roof Buildings A and B at Audeo Charter School (CC22-0950-08). The term of the Agreement is effective June 21, 2022 through the completion of the project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed: $750,105.00. Budget Strings: 9609-81504-00-5711-8100-0000-01000-0000 and 5686-81500-00-5100-8100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This project consists of the removal of existing roofs and replacing them with new polyvinyl-chloride (PVC) roofs on buildings A and B at Audeo Charter School at 3420-3430 Camino Del Rio North, San Diego, CA 92108.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on May 20, 2022. The district received a total of three bids from Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction, Commercial & Industrial Roofing Co., Inc., and Sylvester Roofing Co., Inc. After evaluating the bids, staff determined Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE), which established a three percent required participation of DVBEs for all district construction contracting opportunities, the recommended contractor, Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction, submitted a three percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the contract to Re-Roof Buildings A and B at Audeo Charter School is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended). On May 15, 2018, the board determined that the Students Success Programs, Inc., Whole Site Modernization Project (WSM) and related site construction and lease at district-owned property at 3420 and 3430 Camino Del Rio North, San Diego, CA 92108 was exempt from further environmental review pursuant to CEQA Guidelines Section 15301. The Board also directed staff to file a Notice of Exemption (NOE) for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County and the California State Clearinghouse, Office of Planning and Research which was completed on May 17, 2018 (attached). Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that execution of the proposed contract and subsequent construction of the proposed improvements have been fully analyzed in the previously approved NOE and no further CEQA review is required.

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $1,938,289.00.  Budget Strings: 9609-81504-00-5711-8100-0000-01000-0000 and 5686-81500-00-5100-8100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The project consists of providing slope repair and related site improvements at Grant TK-8 School located at 1425 Washington Place, San Diego, CA 92103.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on May 20, 2022. The district received a total of two bids from Blue Pacific Engineering Construction and Straight Line General Contractors, Inc. After evaluating the bids, staff determined Straight Line General Contractors, Inc., to be the lower responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011 board approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE), which established a three percent required participation of DVBEs for all district construction contracting opportunities, the recommended contractor, Straight Line General Contractors, Inc., submitted a 3.5 percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The award of the proposed agreement and subsequent construction of the slope repair and related site improvements at Grant TK-8 School (Proposed Project) is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended). On July 2, 2019, the Department of Toxic Substance Control (DTSC), acting as lead agency under the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), prepared and filed a Notice of Exemption (NOE) for a Removal Action Workplan (RAW) for the excavation and complete removal of waste debris on an existing slope at Grant TK-8 school (Attachment 1). DTSC found that the Proposed Project is exempt from environmental review pursuant to CEQA Guidelines Section 15330 (Class 30), which allows for any minor cleanup actions taken to prevent, minimize, stabilize, mitigate, or eliminate the release or threat of release of a hazardous waste or substance which are small or medium removal actions. The nature of this project would not require subsequent institutional controls, a long-term operations and maintenance agreement with the DTSC, or the implementation of a land use covenant.

 

Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that approval of the proposed agreement is consistent with the DTSC approved CEQA NOE and no further CEQA review is required.

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed Amount: $4,000,000.00. Budget String: Various Site Identified Funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of December 13, 2020 through January 18, 2022:  $1,858,677.18.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district sought a competitive solution for an online marketplace to purchase a variety of textbooks, library books, educational films, audio-visual materials, test materials, workbooks, and instructional computer software packages, or periodicals at competitive pricing. On Dec 12, 2017, the board authorized the district to purchase educational materials and related supplies through Prince William County Public Schools Cooperative Agreement, which expired January 18, 2022. The term of the board's Authorization was December 13, 2017 through December 12, 2020, for a total not-to-exceed amount of $1,280,000.00.

 

On September 28, 2021, the board authorized an Additional Spending Authorization to continue to purchase educational materials and related supplies through Prince William County Public Schools Cooperative Agreement, which was to expire January 18, 2022. The new total amount was approved at not-to-exceed $2,000,000.00.

 

On December 1, 2021 Prince William County Schools renewed their cooperative agreement with Amazon Business through January 18, 2024.  This new authorization will allow the district to continue procuring a variety of textbooks, library books, educational films, audio-visual materials, test materials, workbooks, and instructional computer software packages, or periodicals at competitive pricing for the next two years.

 

On July 8, 2014, the board received the final report from the Environmental Sustainability Advisory Committee. Included in this report as a "Dream Big" idea was a recommended action to join or create larger purchasing cooperatives. A purchasing cooperative establishes various contracts, which aggregate the total purchases from many government entities resulting in lower costs to governmental entities who utilize these contracts.

BACKGROUND: On January 28, 2020, the board authorized the utilization of the State of California Addendum to Oregon's Master Agreement with W.W. Grainger, Inc., to continue providing industrial supplies, equipment, and lighting products (No. 8496/Addendum No 7-18-51-02/GD20-0381-19) for $1,200,000,00. On April 27, 2021, the board authorized the additional spending of $800,000.00 to bring the new not-to-exceed total to $2,000,000.00. This additional spending authorization will allow Physical Plant Operations (PPO) to install LED lighting throughout district sites, which saves energy and lowers maintenance costs, as well as provides better lighting for students and staff. The new not-to-exceed total is $3,000,000.00. The term of the contract remains the same.
