46. Determine that the Removal and Replacement of Playground Matting, Surfacing, and Playground Equipment at Six District School Sites is Exempt From Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act Guidelines Section 15061(b)(3); and Agreement with Robertson Industries, Inc., to Replace Playground Pour-in-Place Surfacing at Six Sites; BUDGETED: YES, ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE FUND
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$922,729.37
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Ongoing and Major Maintenance Fund

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the removal and replacement of playground matting, surfacing, and playground equipment at six district school sites is exempt from further environmental review pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act Guidelines section 15061(b)(3); and Approve Agreement with Robertson Industries, Inc., to provide and install playground pour-in-place surfacing at Field, Jones, Miramar Ranch, Penn, Vista Grande, and Walker elementary schools (CP22-1049-33). The term of the Agreement is June 21, 2022 through the completion of the project.

 

Authorize the rejection of bid from SpectraSystems, Inc., dba SpectraTurf, as non-responsive to the terms and conditions of the bid. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $922,729.37. Budget Strings: 9609-81504-00-5711-8100-0000-01000-000 and 5686-81500-00-5100-8100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This project consists of providing and installing playground pour-in-pace surfacing at Field, Jones, Miramar Ranch, Penn, Vista Grande, and Walker Elementary Schools. Spiral slides and associated components will also be replaced at Miramar Ranch and Walker Elementary Schools.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on May 12, 2022. The district received a total of three bids from Built Pacific, Inc., Robertson Industries, Inc., and SpectraSystems, Inc., dba SpectraTurf. After evaluating the bids, staff determined Robertson Industries, Inc., to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. However, due to limited scope and resources for DVBE, the mandatory DVBE participation requirement of three percent was waived for this project.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The Proposed Project can be found exempt from environmental review pursuant to CEQA Guidelines section 15061(b)(3). The activity is covered by the general rule which exempts activities that can be seen with certainty to have no possibility for causing a significant effect on the environment. The removal and replacement of playground matting and equipment at existing developed school sites would not create any significant environmental impacts.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): Section 15300.2 of the State CEQA Guidelines specifies several exceptions to the use of a categorical exemption.

  • Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the Project is to be located – a Project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may, in a particularly sensitive environment, be significant, therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the Project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies. The Proposed Project does not fall within this class of exemption. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant. The Proposed Project consists of replacement of existing facilities and would not result in cumulative construction impacts because no ongoing projects would occur at the same time as the construction of the Proposed Project. Operational cumulative impacts would not occur because no operational changes are proposed. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. The Proposed Project consists of replacement of existing facilities where no changes in use would occur. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. There are no new physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new impacts to scenic highways. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new hazardous materials impacts. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource. The Proposed Project would result in the replacement of non-historic playground facilities. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement as described above.

 

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.627.7151, jhensley@sandi.net]

The term of the Agreement is June 21, 2022 through completion of the project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $696,780.00. Budget string: 9125-90404-00-5751-8500-0000-21400-8534. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Zamorano Elementary School asphalt repair project consists of the following: asphalt/concrete repairs throughout the site, including removal and replacement of asphalt/concrete, patch, grind, overlay, fix tripping hazards, seal coat and re-striping of asphalt.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on May 19, 2022. The district received a total of five bids from Blue Pacific Engineering Construction, Inc., Kirk Paving, Inc., Ramona Paving & Construction Corporation, RAP Engineering, Inc., and Frank and Son Paving, Inc. After evaluating the bids, staff determined Ramona Paving & Construction Corporation to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. The recommended contractor, Ramona Paving & Construction Corporation, submitted a three percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The Zamorano Elementary School Asphalt Repair Project (Proposed Project) is subject to the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA). However, the project is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Section 15301 – Existing Facilities (Class 1). A Class 1 exemption consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. The key consideration is whether the project involves negligible or no expansion of use. As described above, the Proposed Project consists of asphalt and concrete repairs at an existing school site and would not result in the expansion of the existing use. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 categorical exemption is appropriate for the Proposed Project.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): Section 15300.2 of the State CEQA Guidelines specifies several exceptions to the use of a categorical exemption.

  • Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the Project is to be located – a Project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may, in a particularly sensitive environment, be significant, therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the Project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies. The Proposed Project does not fall within this class of exemption. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant. The Proposed Project consists of the repair and replacement of existing facilities and would not result in cumulative construction impacts because no ongoing projects would occur at the same time as the construction of the Proposed Project. Operational cumulative impacts would not occur because no operational changes are proposed. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. The Proposed Project consists of the repair and replacement of existing facilities where no changes in use would occur. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. There are no new physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new impacts to scenic highways. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new hazardous materials impacts. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource. The Proposed Project would result in the replacement of non-historic asphalt and concrete. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement as described above.

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of November 1, 2021 through June 1, 2022: $194,812.80.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Department advertised bid No. GD22-0955-03 on April 7 and April 14, 2022, to competitively solicit bids for Xerographic copy paper 8.5” x 11”. On May 5, 2022, a public bid opening was conducted. There were four bidders: Contract Paper Group, Inc., Liberty Paper, ODP Business Solutions, LLC, and Kelly Spicer Paper. During the bid evaluation, it was determined that Contact Paper Group's paper did not pass the district's sun test so they were disqualified from bidding.  Kelly Paper did not acknowledge the addendum in PlanetBids and therefore they were deemed non-responsive. Of the two responsible and responsive bidders Liberty Paper and ODP Business Solutions, ODP Business Solutions had the lowest price. Recommendation for award goes to ODP Business Solutions, LLC. Due to the volatility of the market this contract is only for six months. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Gene Robinson, Director, Transportation, and Distribution Services, Office of the Operations Support Officer, 858.496.8710, grobinson@sandi.net]

Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is May 27, 2022 through June 30, 2022.


FISCAL IMPACT: The fiscal impact for all 2021-22 NPS and NPA agreements was previously approved on September 14, 2021 at a not-to-exceed amount of $17,387,638.00. There is no additional fiscal impact as a result of this approval recommendation.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: The 2020-21 fiscal impact for all NPS and NPA agreements was previously captured and approved on the September 14, 2021 Agenda.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.
 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.
 

BACKGROUND: On September 14, 2021, the board authorized payments to Nonpublic Schools (NPS)and Nonpublic Agencies (NPA) to continue providing special education and related services to students with exceptional needs as mandated by individual students' Individualized Education Program (IEP) and by state and federal laws during the term of these Agreements.
 

This new Agreement with RO Health, LLC, is being added to the original board approval from September 14, 2021, due to an urgent need for student placement at their facility for services provided and required for said student.
 

The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) collaborates with the SELPA directors from each of the County SELPAs to negotiate a template agreement to be used by each, which sets the terms, conditions, and rates for agreements with CDE-certified non-public schools and agencies.
 

When all negotiations are completed, this Master Contract, along with the approved rate sheets, is distributed to all school districts in San Diego County for the creation of individual agreements with identified CDE-approved NPS/NPA student services providers. Proposed NPS/NPA agreements are then submitted to the respective school boards for approval. In compliance with a provision in each Master Contract agreement which provides for payment at the currently approved rates to these providers until there is a ratification of a successor agreement. As individual Master Contracts are signed and returned to the district, they will be submitted for board approval.

57. Agreement with PowerSchool Group, LLC, to Continue Providing Districtwide Support for the PowerSchool Student Information System and Related Applications; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS SITE IDENTIFIED FUNDS
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$9,227,005.96
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Site Identified Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with PowerSchool Group, LLC, to continue providing districtwide support for the PowerSchool Student Information System and related applications (SW23-0139-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement, and the execution of additional Agreement term extensions. The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2027.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $9,227,005.96.

Budget Strings:

5538-00006-00-5841-7700-0000-01000-0000, 5538-00006-00-5842-7700-0000-01000-0000 and 5538-00006-00-5853-7700-0000-01000-0000, Integrated Technology Mandated Expenses General Funds

 

5538-00005-00-5853-7700-0000-01000-0000 and 5538-00005-00-5841-7700-0000-01000-0000, Integrated Technology Fixed Expenses General Funds

 

5538-32131-00-5841-1000-1110-01000-3844, Integrated Technology ESSER Funds

 

5467-00000-00-5100-2490-0000-01000-0000, Leadership and Learning General Funds

 

5538-74120-00-5841-1000-1110-01000-0000, A-G Grant Funds

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $1,626,748.58.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On December 13, 2011, the board approved implementation of the Five-Year Enterprise Software Plan which included replacing the Student Information System (SIS). To support this plan, the board approved Agreement SW-12-0001-13, on May 15, 2012, with NCS Pearson, Inc., to provide PowerSchool as the successor SIS. On May 10, 2016, the board approved a change from NCS Pearson, Inc., to the newly formed PowerSchool Group, LLC.

 

A lot has changed in the last five years in the K12 software industry; PowerSchool is a leading example of embracing and investing in those changes. The company has grown by expanding their business which included purchasing several K12 software companies to complement their offerings and continuing to build an integrated ecosphere of products that work together. A handful of these companies were products that the district used and continues to use are now under the PowerSchool umbrella of products which are regularly being improved and enhanced for a better student, family and/or staff experience. In addition to adding technology through K12 software acquisitions, PowerSchool also developed several new systems that leverage the value of cloud technologies and were very timely during COVID. Some included digital communication tools that the district purchased to facilitate data collection and communications during online learning and continue to do so for tasks such as delivering digital report cards to parents without mailing or sending home and eSignature tools for handling mandated or other forms requiring signatures, along with related reporting indicating status of delivery, reading or pickup.

 

Going forward and to better serve students and families, it is important that both new and existing technology is fully leveraged to communicate from all levels of the district. Coming out of COVID, families more than ever rely on technology to be informed, communicate with school and district staff, and have access to their student’s academic records. As part of this agreement, the district will deploy a Parent Portal Success Program to provide a districtwide and supported deployment to all new and existing families not having a Parent Portal account. This includes executing a well-defined plan and training to sustain internal district resources to offer families access to the Parent Portal when they are enrolled at a San Diego Unified school. The 2022-23 school year will be the tenth full year that San Diego Unified has used PowerSchool as its SIS. During the last ten years, there have been numerous improvements made by both the vendor and the district's Integrated Technology staff to give families, students, and staff a more unified platform to use and rely on for their daily needs. The new Agreement with PowerSchool Group, LLC, will leverage the existing PowerSchool license that that district owns and continue the momentum to keep up with the continuous and evolving demands of a modern SIS. Allowable under Elementary and Secondary Emergency Relief (ESSER) through supporting access to education technology.

 

[Originator/Contact: Toren Allen, Executive Director, Integrated Technology Division, 619.260.5438, tallen@sandi.net]

BACKGROUND: On September 14, 2021 (Agenda Item I.19) the board ratified an Agreement with The Stepping Stones Group, LLC, to provide Speech-Language Pathology services to students with special needs as mandated under State and Federal special education laws. The district does not have sufficient staff to provide speech-language pathology services to district students with identified or suspected special needs as specified in their Individualized Education Plan (IEP). The district is required to contract with outside agencies to provide Speech and Language services due to district employees taking leave for the following reasons: Family leaves, short-term leaves, and long-term leaves.

 

This First Amendment includes an increased hourly rate in order to obtain qualified and experienced providers and also an increase in overall funding to cover the merger of EBS Healthcare with The Stepping Stones Group. This merger has resulted in fewer available contracting companies and more funding for services with The Stepping Stones Group.

Budget Strings:

5451-41244-00-5100-1000-1110-01000-0492 Hoover High School

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 - June 30, 2022: $10,000.00.

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.
 

BACKGROUND: On July 30, 2019 the board approved an Agreement in an amount not-to-exceed $30,000.00 with The Children's Initiative to provide support services for the 21st Century Community Learning Centers (CCLC) After School Safety and Enrichment for Teens (ASSETs) IMIN Program services at various district high schools. The high schools included Crawford, Garfield, Hoover, Kearny SCC, Lincoln, San Diego IS, and Twain. The not to exceed amount of $30,000.00 was for the term of the Agreement.

 

On January 26, 2021 the board approved a First Amendment to Agreement with The Children's Initiative to continue providing support services for the 21st Century Community Learning Centers (CCLC) After School Safety and Enrichment for Teens (ASSETs) IMIN Program services. This First Amendment adds Kearny High School Digital Media and Design and Morse High School to the list of participating schools and adds support services at no additional cost to the district.
 

This Second Amendment revises the high school sites to only continue providing services to Hoover, Lincoln, Twain, Kearny Digital Media and Design, Morse, and Twain High Schools. The Second Amendment extends the term by two years and the compensation for those two years to $20,000.00 for a total not-to-exceed amount of $50,000.00 for the entire term of the Agreement. 

 

The Children's Initiative was a founding member of the San Diego Regional Afterschool consortium in 1998, and has played a significant role in the planning, implementation, evaluation, and sustainability of after school programs in more than 25 school districts within San Diego County, including district implementation and sustainability of the ASSETs IMIN program. The district has been working in collaboration with The Children's Initiative for 19 years providing professional development and a curriculum aligned with California State Standards, designed especially for after-school professionals to increase student academic achievement levels.

 

Support services for the 21st CCLC ASSETs IMIN Program include:


• Career Awareness and Exploration resources for students including speakers and presentations
• Coordinating trainings/presentations for high school students focusing on job readiness/career pathways and/or college readiness
• Site visit support and feedback on how programming aligns with the Quality Standards for Expanded Learning Programs
• Identifying and securing resources to recognize high school students in the IMIN After School Programs

BACKGROUND: On February 22, 2022 the board ratified agreements with multiple service providers to provide psychological services to students with identified or special needs as specified in their Individual Education Plan (IEP) and mandated under state and federal special education laws. These providers included: Sunbelt Staffing, LLC (PS22-0806-37), The Stepping Stones Group (PS22-0806-37), and ProCare Therapy, Inc. (PS22-0807-37).

 

These First Amendments extend the Agreement terms by an additional four years and increase the hourly rates in order to obtain qualified and experienced providers through these agencies so services can be continued.

 

The district does not have sufficient staff to provide psychological services to district students with identified or suspected special needs as specified in their Individual Education Program (IEP), and as mandated under state and federal special education laws. The district will establish a pool of qualified psychologists from these providers, to meet the needs of students. The district is required to contract with outside agencies to provide Speech and Language services due to district employees taking leave for the following reasons: family leaves, short-term leaves, and long-term leaves. 


California Government Code 53060 grants the district the authority to contract with and employ persons for the furnishing of special services if such persons are specially trained, experienced, and competent to perform the special services required.

Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$2,000,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Title II Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Teach For America (TFA) to provide professional development and recruitment of leaders who reflect the diversity of district students (SV23-0231-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement.  The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $2,000,000.00. Budget String: 5508-40351-00-5100-2140-0000-01000-0000. The cost of services is based on the number of new hires during the term of the agreement.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: The Independent Citizens Oversight Committee on Racial Justice and Equity was provided with an update during its May 11, 2022 meeting.

 

BACKGROUND: Teach For America (TFA) will support one of TEACH-LEAD San Diego’s leadership development pathways by providing the following services:

1.1. Cohort-based professional development and coaching services for participating district employees, as well as online data storage services to facilitate such cohort-based professional development and coaching services (the “Professional Development and Data Storage Services”). Teach For America will collaborate in the planning and implementation of these services with district staff.

1.2. Recruitment of Teach For America Alumni Educators and Leaders to serve as site based leaders (e.g., principals or associate principals). The district’s grow your own educator and leader pipeline, TEACH-LEAD San Diego (see Goal 4 of the Local Control and Accountability Plan), will leverage the support of this partnership with TFA to increase the diversity of leaders to reflect the diversity of the student population through support and training of new and aspiring leaders.

This agreement is designed to provide recruitment and selection support as well as professional development to ensure the retention of diverse leaders of color. The district and Teach for America San Diego have been in partnership since 2012 to recruit, select and train individuals committed to closing the opportunity gap by serving as effective leaders specifically equipped to enhance student achievement in under-resourced school systems. The prior agreements were for the purpose of recruiting classroom educators; however, this agreement will focus on the recruitment and retention of diverse leaders.

Teach For America San Diego is building an Alumni Recruitment Program (the “Program”) that seeks to mobilize Teach For America’s alumni (“TFA Alumni”) to accelerate the pace of change towards educational equity through the development of school principals and associate principals. Teach for America’s commitment to diversity and equity is essential to this partnership. All TFA candidates are subject to established district hiring practices and to the Collective Negotiations Agreement between the district and the Administrator's Association of San Diego (AASD).

[Originator/Contact: Acacia Thede, Chief Human Resources Officer, 619.725.8043, athede@sandi.net]

66. Agreement with Bay Promo, LLC, to provide the District with KF94 Masks; BUDGETED: YES, ESSER III FUNDS
Meeting
Jun 21, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Bay Promo, LLC, (GD22-1104-30), to provide the district with KF94 Masks for Adult and Youth. Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate an Agreement. The term of this Agreement is June 22, 2022 through June 21, 2023. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $103,440.00. Budget String: 5633-32131-00-5100-2100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On May 12, 2022 the district advertised Bid No. GD22-1104-30, for two weeks in The Daily Transcript to competitively solicit bids for KF94 masks. On May 26, 2022 at 1:00 PM PST the public bid opening was conducted via PlanetBids. As a result of this Bid, the district received 13 proposals, Bay Promo, LLC, was deemed to be the lowest responsive bidder. The Award of this Agreement will assist the district in mitigating the Covid-19 risk to its students and staff.  Allowable under Elementary and Secondary Emergency Relief (ESSER) through supporting public health protocols via purchase of personal protective equipment.

 

[Originator/Contact: Gary Petill, Interim Chief Operations Officer, 858.627.7218, gpetill@sandi.net]
